channel.title: c2a4x_labboard5
channel.description:
Hello, I apologise that my first thread isn't very helpful to the other folks that have been here longer than I have, but I do wish to know what, for the more scientifically-inclined/Stormseeker, these snippets of the asset c2a4x_labboard5 say:
[url=https://localhost/mybb/attachment.php?aid=3760][img]https://localhost/mybb/attachment.php?thumbnail=3760[/img][/url][url=https://localhost/mybb/attachment.php?aid=3761][img]https://localhost/mybb/attachment.php?thumbnail=3761[/img][/url]
The former has a Feynman diagram accompanying it, and the latter an equation. I can upload them if you wish.
Thank you in advance.

item.title: c2a4x_labboard5
item.dc:creator: Benthogyrinus
item.description:
stormseeker:

First bit is Gravimetric Sheer (shear), which is actually technobabble, and commonly used in things like star trek to refer to effects created by gravity or particle interaction. (hey its a science fiction weapon), and is referring to the reaction of the magnetic calibrators on the tau particle beam.

Second bit is the tangential component of an electromagnetic fields vector (see maxwells equations).

The boards are fluff though remember, and arranged to be artistic as well as interesting.

Thank you very much. I understand it was a silly question to ask, but I appreciate it nonetheless.

Read full topic

item.title: c2a4x_labboard5
item.dc:creator: KevinJRattman
item.description:
Majoring methemagics I know I am not the most scientifically inclined person here, but I had examined the whiteboard texture to get used to Dr. Horn’s writing and it seems the first word in the first page is “gravimetric”. First I thought it starts with “ge…” but I noticed he writes “r” like “e”, as seen in “Do not wipe the board! - Dr. Horn”.

The word under it refer to the inhomogeneous electro-magnetic wave eq but I’m not sure the corrolation between it and the gravimetric science.

The second letter in the second picture I thought it could be covariant. I noticed after Poynting vector mentioned ( S = c/4ㅠ E X B - using CGM notation). My friend suggested “coefficient” but it lacks extra f to be that case.

Read full topic
